Jo Bennett

Minimum wages are essential because no economy has free movement of labour, so poorly paid workers are not on an even footing to negotiate for higher wages. The claim that they cause unemployment is not supported by the evidence so far in the UK. We've had a minimum wage for 10 years now (at around twice the rate in the US) and those claims were made by the CBI and were shown to be without foundation. The fact of the matter is that those jobs paying minimum wage generally can't be got rid of, and even when they can the wages are a relatively small component of the cost of production that it's not efficient to shed jobs. This leads to my second point, that because wages are only a fraction of production costs, prices will not rise at the same rate as the minimum wage so they have a proportionally redistributive effect.
 
 Given the rate of increase in boardroom pay I am still flabbergasted that people have the gall to claim that those at the bottom need to tighten their belts to combat inflation.

Ethmi, you're taking a very myopic approach to this issue. The objective of the taxes hike for businesses and business heads is to fund education programs that will further boost the lowest rung of the workforce, justifying their pay increase. If they raise minimum wage, for businesses this is a higher expense which will cut into profits. But its the profits that are going to be hit by the higher taxes anyway. So would you, as a business owner prefer more profits to pay more taxes, or more expenses to offset the tax burden a bit? Not only that, with the hike in minimum wage, we might expect to see stricter educational prerequisites for entry-level jobs. And that's why the educational programs that will be funded by these taxes will be so important. Ultimately, the net effect of the plan will be higher productivity for all involved. 
 
 As for inflation, I would expect to see prices increase to compensate for higher cost of labor, but we have had a ridculous rate of inflation as it is, with no wage increases for the same middle class that you are championing here. They will be no worse off with Obama's plan than they will be with Bush's record debt-acceleration war strategy. And if more lower class citizens do benefit from the education thrust that Obama is promising, then it will actually benefit the middle class greatly.
